awd_titl_txt: AM-WATCH: Additive Manufacturing - Workforce Advancement Training Coalition and Hub
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing (AM) is rapidly changing the design and production of all kinds of products, from those used in daily life to critical parts utilized in advanced technologies. With the increased national and global focus, there is clear evidence of the growing demand for technicians in AM. The Additive Manufacturing Workforce Advancement Training Coalition and Hub (AM-WATCH) is being established to address gaps in the knowledge base of 21st century technicians to ensure they are prepared for advanced career placement. This project is significantly enhancing and expanding AM resources developed by prior NSF projects (including remote facilities, learning curriculum, and educator workshops) to encompass hands-on desktop 3D printer-building modules, equipment operation/maintenance curriculum, and additional remotely-accessible equipment laboratories. In addition, AM-WATCH is establishing a number of cutting edge AM innovations and targeting the engagement of students, including those in underserved and under-represented groups, in STEM and other technical careers. 

The objective of AM-WATCH is to address gaps in the current knowledge base of technicians through the development of curriculum and educational materials, delivery of professional development activities, support provided to 30+ community college and high school instructors per year, and expanded outreach activities targeting K-12 and community college teachers and students. Tennessee Technological University is collaborating with Community Colleges (CC), four-year universities, the ATE National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education, a national laboratory, industry, and government in the development of cutting-edge and multi-dimensional curriculum, activities, and toolkits for instructors.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this advanced technological education (ATE) project was to establish an Additive Manufacturing Workforce Advancement Training Coalition and Hub (AM-WATCH) to address current gaps in the knowledge base of 21st century technicians through the development of AM-WATCH educational knowledge blocks, delivery of professional development activities, support to a number of community college and high school instructors per year, and expand outreach activities targeting K-12 and community college teachers and students.

Tennessee Technological University, in partnership with Sinclair College, Edmonds College's ATE National Resource Center for Materials Technology Education, University of Louisville, and Oak Ridge National Laboratory, collaborated in developing cutting-edge and multi-dimensional educational modules and activities for community college and high school STEM faculty focused on Additive Manufacturing (AM) technologies and practices needed for today's AM workforce.

The project deliverables had a three-fold focus on 1) technical preparation in currently practiced AM technologies, expertise in design for, use and maintenance, 2) professional practice and leadership in AM and 3) innovation and techno-entrepreneurship making use of AM and related technologies.

With the increased focus on AM nationally and internationally, there is clear evidence of the strong and growing demand for technicians in AM. The current efforts in technician education are being rapidly outpaced by industry adoption of AM creating a skills gap. This project built upon the investigators' previous successes in technician education and connected local high schools, community colleges, industry and universities, allowing educators and students to show some original AM career pathways with multiple resources and activities. The AM-WATCH Project was conducted through the following primary uniquely developed resources and activities:

1) Educational modules covering a broad spectrum of the topics related to AM processes, technologies, safety, maintenance, and building a 3D Printer were developed in MOOC (massive open online course) and hard copy formats for the easy and free access of the educators' use, and placed on the project website for easy download and access.

2) In order to provide a broader access to regional community colleges and high schools, two-day train-the-trainer studios were offered in the states of TN, KY, OH, and WA. Participants were introduced to the developed educational materials and they learned how to build, operate and maintain a 3D Printer. Instructional delivery component of each studio was also recorded and shared via project website.

3) The project team developed a list of skills sets necessary for 21st century AM technicians. Eventually, these skills sets were tied to ABET student outcomes.

4) ABET accreditation is a quality endorsement of a higher education program and that has a number of specific criteria in line with general and program specific outcomes. Usually, educational programs have difficulty in measuring the attainment of ABET Student Outcomes. The project team has developed some best practices to help the community college educators to understand the core of ABET Student Outcome attainment via design and AM practices of the AM-WATCH activities.

5) Sharing AM resources and capabilities in each AM-WATCH Hub was made possible with the use of network cameras. Through this innovation, each institution was able to share the 3D Printing equipment and machines, and present these to students in other campuses and offer printing support whenever needed.

6) The project developed and implemented an online short lecture series. Recordings of these lectures were uploaded to the project website.  The goal is to help the high school and community college educators learn the latest AM topics and also let the educators share their AM best practices.

7) Innovation and Entrepreneurship (I&E) is an educational component which is highly needed by community college and high school STEM educators to help their student grasp the notion and implement it in their courses and labs. The project developed a series of MOOCs about the I&E concepts and these were introduced to studio participants in all project events.

8) AM-WATCH resources and activities establish a life-long learning environment so that anybody can learn from, and implement the project deliverables in their STEM courses and labs.


Last Modified: 10/26/2021
Modified by: Ismail Fidan
